case_name: Raja Rajinder Chand v. the adnamaliks

facts.text: Raja Rajinder Chand brought six suits in the Court of the Subordinate Judge of Kangra for declaration of ownership of all pine trees on lands of defendants in Nadaun Jagir.

anchor.surface_text: These are six appeals by the plaintiff Raja Rajinder Chand, the superior landlord  alamalik  of Nadaun Jagir in the district of Kangra. He brought six suits in the Court of the Subordinate Judge of Kangra for a declaration that he was the owner of all pine  chil-pinus longifolia  trees standing on the lands of the defendants within the said Jagir and for a permanent injunction restraining the latter from interfering with his rights of ownership and extraction of resin from the said trees.

facts.text: Defendants are adna maliks, inferior landlords in possession of the lands on which the pine trees stand.

anchor.surface_text: The defendants, who are the adnamaliks  inferior landlords , pleaded that they were the owners in possession of the lands on which the trees stood, that the trees were their property,

facts.text: Plaintiff claimed damages for loss from tapping of pine trees by defendants from March 24, 1940, up to date suits were brought.

anchor.surface_text: He also claimed specified sums as damages for the loss caused to him from the tapping of pine trees by different defendants from March 24, 1940, up to the date when the suits were brought.

facts.text: Suits Nos. 544, 548, 545, 547, 546 and 549 of 1940 filed in Court of Subordinate Judge, 4th Class, Kangra.

anchor.surface_text: of the Court of Subordinate Judge, 4th Class, Kangra in Suits Nos. 544, 548, 545, 547, 546 and 549 of 1940.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge dismissed suits on July 24, 1941, holding no proof of ownership and suits barred by time.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Subordinate Judge, who dealt with the suits in the first instance, held that the present appellant had failed to prove his ownership of the trees. He further held that the suits were barred by time.

facts.text: District Judge, Hoshiarpur reversed Subordinate Judge on ownership and limitation, allowed appeals on July 31, 1942.

anchor.surface_text: Raja Rajinder Chand then preferred appeals from the judgment and decrees of the learned Subordinate Judge, and the appeals were heard by the learned District Judge of Hoshiarpur. The latter reversed the finding of the ,learned Subordinate Judge on the question of ownership and held that the present appellant had established his right to the trees in question.

facts.text: Punjab High Court on December 30, 1949, reversed District Judge on ownership, agreed on limitation, dismissed suits.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgment and decrees of the Punjab High Court dated December 30, 1949, in Civil Regular Appeals Nos. 1567, 1568, 1569, 1570, 1573 an 1574 of 1942

facts.text: Supreme Court appeals Civil Appeals Nos. 196 to 201 of 1953, judgment on October 23, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 196 to 201 of 1953. Appeals from the judgment and decrees of the Punjab High Court dated December 30, 1949,

facts.text: Suit lands in Badhog and Jasai tappas within Nadaun Jagir, district of Kangra.

anchor.surface_text: Admittedly, the suit lands lie in Badhog and Jasai tappas companyprised within the Jagir of Nadaun in the district of Kangra.

facts.text: Raja Sansar Chand, last independent ruler of Kangra, died in 1824.

anchor.surface_text: The last independent ruler of Kangra was Raja Sansar Chand who died in the year 1824.

facts.text: Raja Jodhbir Chand, son of Raja Sansar Chand, granted Nadaun Jagir by Maharaja Ranjit Singh.

anchor.surface_text: Maharaja Ranjit Singh came to Nadaun, and Jodhbir Chand gave his two sisters to the Maharaja. Jodhbir Chand was then created a Raja, with Nadaun and the surrounding companyntry as his Jagir.

facts.text: Raja Rajinder Chand is direct lineal descendant of Raja Jodhbir Chand, fourth in line.

anchor.surface_text: The present appellant, Raja Rajinder Chand, is a direct lineal descendant of Raja Jodhbir Chand, being fourth in the line of descent.

facts.text: Sanad granted to Raja Jodhbir Chand on October 11, 1848, by British Government renewing earlier grant.

anchor.surface_text: He obtained a Sanad from the British Government in 1846 A companyy of that Sanad was number available, but a companyy of a Sanad granted on October 11, 1848, which renewed and clarified the earlier Sanad, was produced

facts.text: Supreme Court holds appellant did not succeed to sovereign rights of independent rulers of Kangra.

anchor.surface_text: We accept these as good and companyvincing reasons for discountenancing the claim of the appellant that the sovereign rights of the independent rulers of Kangra in respect of all royal trees  including pine trees  within Nadaun Jagir had companye down to him.

facts.text: Sanad of 1848 grants land revenue (Jama Rs. 26,270/10/3), not rights to pine trees on cultivated lands.

anchor.surface_text: the total Jama whereof was Rs. 26,270/10/3 per annum approximately... We agree therefore with the High Court that on a true and proper companystruction of the Sanad, it is impossible to spell out of its terms a grant in favour of Raja Jodhbir Chand of the right to all pine trees on cultivated and proprietary lands.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds Wajib-ul-arz entries do not establish grant or surrender of right to pine trees on proprietary lands.

anchor.surface_text: we hold, for the reasons already given by us, that the entries in the Wajib-ul-arz with regard to the right of the Raja in respect of chil trees standing on cultivated and proprietary lands of the adna-maliks, do number and cannot show any existing custom

facts.text: Supreme Court dismisses appeals, appellant fails to establish ownership of pine trees.

anchor.surface_text: For these reasons, we hold that the appellant has failed to establish his claim to the pine trees, and the decision of the High Court is companyrect. The appeals fail and are dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: It is pertinent to quote here the following observations of Lord Dunedin in Vajesingji Joravarsingji v. Secretary of State for India 1  When a territory is acquired by a sovereign State for the first time that is an act of State. It matters number how the acquisition has been brought about. It may be by companyquest, it may be by cession following on treaty, it may be by occupation of territory hitherto unoccupied by a recognised ruler. In all cases the result is the same. Any inhabitant of the territory can make good in the municipal companyrts established by the new sovereign only such rights as that sovereign has, through his officers, recognised. Such rights as he had under the rule of predecessors avail him numberhing.

concepts.interpretation: Rights under previous sovereign not enforceable unless recognized by new sovereign

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: er an enquiry having been made and a report having been submitted to the Nawab Governor- General. Appended to the Sanad was a list of tappas and villa

concepts.unlisted_description: Acquisition of territory extinguishes prior rights unless recognized

anchor.surface_text: It is, we think, well settled that the ordinary rule applicable to grants made by a subject does number apply to grants made by the sovereign authority and grants made by the Sovereign are to be companystrued most favourably for the Sovereign. This general rule, however, is capable of important relaxations in favour of the subject. It is necessary to refer here to such only of those relaxations as have a bearing on the company- struction of the document before us thus, if the intention is obvious, a fair and liberal interpretation must be given to the grant to enable it to take effect and the operative part, if plainly expressed, may take effect numberwithstanding qualifications in the recitals. In cases where the grant is for valuable companysideration, it is companystrued in favour of the grantee, for the honour of the Sovereign and where two companystructions are possible, one valid and the other void that which is valid ought to be preferred, for the honour of the Sovereign ought to be more regarded than the Sovereigns profit  see para 670 at p. 315 of Halsburys Laws of England, Vol. VII, s. 12, Simonds Ed. .

concepts.interpretation: Strictly in favor of sovereign unless intention obvious or valuable consideration; applied to hold Sanad grants only land revenue, not tree rights

concepts.interpretation: Records existing customs, cannot create new rights; entries cannot show surrender of sovereign right

issues.text: whether all pine trees standing on the lands in suit were the property of the plaintiff, i.e., the present appellant

anchor.surface_text: The first question was-whether all pine trees standing on the lands in suit were the property of the plaintiff, i.e., the present appellant.

issues.text: whether the suits were barred by limitation

anchor.surface_text: The second question was one of limitation, and the third question related to the quantum of damages claimed by the appellant.

issues.text: the quantum of damages claimed by the appellant

anchor.surface_text: the third question related to the quantum of damages claimed by the appellant. The learned Subordinate Judge, who dealt with the suits in the first instance, held that the present appellant had failed to prove his ownership of the trees.

issues.text: whether the present appellant has been able to establish his right to all pine chil trees standing on the suit lands of the defendants

anchor.surface_text: The short but important question which arises in these appeals is whether the present appellant has been able to establish his right to all pine chil trees standing on the suit lands of the defendants. The question is of some importance, as it affects the rights of ala and adna maliks in Nadaun Jagir.

issues.text: whether the present appellant could claim the sovereign rights of Raja Sansar Chand who was an independent ruler of Kangra

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges of the High Court held, in agreement with the learned Subordinate Judge, that the present appellant could not claim the sovereign rights of Raja Sansar Chand who was an independent ruler of Kangra. For this finding they gave two reasons firstly, Raja Jodhbir Chand was an illegitimate son of Raja Sansar Chand and could not succeed to the rights of the Raja secondly, whatever rights Raja Sansar Chand had as an independent ruler of Kangra came to an end  so far as his descendants were concerned  with the annexation of his territory by the Sikhs, and Raja Jodhbir Chand merely got an assignment of land revenue to the tune of Rs. 30,000 by the grant. of Nadaun Jagir by Maharaja Ranjit Singh.

issues.text: whether the aforesaid Sanad was a grant primarily of land revenue or it made a grant of other royal rights including the right to all pine trees which is the particular right under consideration in the six suits brought by the appellant

anchor.surface_text: The question now is whether the aforesaid Sanad was a grant primarily of land revenue or it made a grant of other royal rights including the right to all pine trees which is the particular right under consideration in the six suits brought by the appellant. It is, we think, well settled that the ordinary rule applicable to grants made by a subject does not apply to grants made by the sovereign authority and grants made by the Sovereign are to be construed most favourably for the Sovereign.

issues.text: the question before us is as to the true scope and legal effect of these entries. Do they establish a grant of the right to chil trees or, what is the same thing, a surrender of that right, in favour of the Raja by Government

anchor.surface_text: The question before us is as to the true scope and legal effect of these entries. Do they establish a grant of the right to chil trees or, what is the same thing, a surrender of that right, in favour of the Raja by Government? In these cases we are not concerned with trees on public waste lands, not with forest trees and as the High Court has pointed out, we do not know if the lands in suit were initially private waste or recently reclaimed lands.

issues.text: whether the Government claim of privilege in respect of those documents was valid under the law as it stands at present

anchor.surface_text: The Government of the Punjab, however, claimed privilege in respect of those documents, which claim was upheld in the High Court. We have re-examined that claim, and though the State was not a party to this litigation, we heard the learned Advocate-General for the State We found the claim to be valid under the law as it stands at present.

holdings.text: The appellant did not succeed to the sovereign rights of the independent rulers of Kangra in respect of all royal trees including pine trees within Nadaun Jagir.

anchor.surface_text: We accept these as good and convincing reasons for discountenancing the claim of the appellant that the sovereign rights of the independent rulers of Kangra in respect of all royal trees including pine trees within Nadaun Jagir had come down to him.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Raja Jodhbir Chand was illegitimate son; rights ended with Sikh annexation; received only revenue assignment; act of state doctrine applies.

holdings.text: On a true and proper construction of the Sanad of 1848, it is impossible to spell out a grant of the right to all pine trees on cultivated and proprietary lands.

anchor.surface_text: We agree therefore with the High Court that on a true and proper construction of the Sanad, it is impossible to spell out of its terms a grant in favour of Raja Jodhbir Chand of the right to all pine trees on cultivated and proprietary lands.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sovereign grants construed favorably for sovereign; specifies jama (revenue) only; no mention of trees; conditions limit to revenue receipt.

holdings.text: The suits were not barred by limitation.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents have not contested before us the correctness of the finding of two of the Courts below that the suits were not barred by time therefore, the question of limitation is no longer a live question

holdings.reasoning_summary: Respondents do not contest lower courts' findings; issue no longer live.

holdings.text: The entries in the Wajib-ul-arz do not and cannot show any existing custom or establish a grant or surrender of the right to chil trees on cultivated and proprietary lands.

anchor.surface_text: we hold, for the reasons already given by us, that the entries in the Wajib-ul-arz with regard to the right of the Raja in respect of chil trees standing on cultivated and proprietary lands of the adna-maliks, do not and cannot show any existing custom

holdings.reasoning_summary: Wajib-ul-arz records existing customs only (PLRA ss.31,44), cannot create rights or infer sovereign surrender; presumption displaced by history, confusion, scope.

holdings.text: The Government claim of privilege in respect of the documents is valid under the law as it stands at present.

anchor.surface_text: The Government of the Punjab, however, claimed privilege in respect of those documents, which claim was upheld in the High Court. We have re-examined that claim... We found the claim to be valid under the law as it stands at present.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Re-examined claim; heard Advocate-General; upheld as valid.

holdings.text: The appellant has failed to establish his claim to the pine trees; appeals fail and are dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: For these reasons, we hold that the appellant has failed to establish his claim to the pine trees, and the decision of the High Court is correct. The appeals fail and are dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Failed on all grounds: no sovereign succession, sanad only revenue, wajib no grant/custom; High Court correct.

holdings.text: There should be no order as to costs either in the High Court or in the Courts below.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances of these cases, where much of the doubt as respects the right claimed arose out of the entries made in the Wajib-ul-arz, the High Court properly directed that there would be no order for costs either in the High Court or in the Courts below.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Doubt from wajib entries justifies no costs order.

precedents.citation: Vajesingji Joravarsingji v. Secretary of State for India 1

anchor.surface_text: It is pertinent to quote here the following observations of Lord Dunedin in Vajesingji Joravarsingji v. Secretary of State for India 1  When a territory is acquired by a sovereign State for the first time that is an act of State. It matters not how the acquisition has been brought about. It may be by conquest, it may be by cession following on treaty, it may be by occupation of territory hitherto unoccupied by a recognised ruler. In all cases the result is the same.

precedents.case_name: Vajesingji Joravarsingji v. Secretary of State for India
precedents.cited_proposition: When a territory is acquired by a sovereign State for the first time that is an act of State. It matters not how the acquisition has been brought about. [...] Any inhabitant of the territory can make good in the municipal courts established by the new sovereign only such rights as that sovereign has, through his officers, recognised. Such rights as he had under the rule of predecessors avail him nothing.
precedents.cited_holding: Any inhabitant of the territory can make good in the municipal courts established by the new sovereign only such rights as that sovereign has, through his officers, recognised. Such rights as he had under the rule of predecessors avail him nothing.

precedents.citation: Rajah Venkata Narasimha Appa Row Bahadur v. Rajah Narayya Appa Row Bahadur 1

anchor.surface_text: the views of the revenue authorities as to the effect or construction of a grant or the intention of Government in respect of a grant, do not conclude the matter or bind the civil Courts.  See Rajah Venkata Narasimha Appa Row Bahadur v. Rajah Narayya Appa Row Bahadur 1  . The same comments apply to the Wajib-ul-arz of 1899-1900  Ex. P-6  and of 1910-15  Ex. P-4 . They no doubt say that the pine trees on the lands comprised within the Khatas of adna-maliks are the property of the Raja Sahib.

precedents.case_name: Rajah Venkata Narasimha Appa Row Bahadur v. Rajah Narayya Appa Row Bahadur
precedents.cited_proposition: The views of the revenue authorities as to the effect or construction of a grant or the intention of Government in respect of a grant, do not conclude the matter or bind the civil Courts.

precedents.citation: Dakas Khan v. Ghulam Kasim Khan 1

anchor.surface_text: A large number of decisions in which entries of the Wajib-ul-arz or the Riwaji-i-am and the value to be given to them were considered, have been cited before us. [...] As was observed by the Privy Council in Dakas Khan v. Ghulam Kasim Khan 1 , the Wajib-ul-arz, though it does not create a title, gives rise to a presumption in its support which prevails unless the presumption is properly displaced

precedents.case_name: Dakas Khan v. Ghulam Kasim Khan
precedents.cited_proposition: the Wajib-ul-arz, though it does not create a title, gives rise to a presumption in its support which prevails unless the presumption is properly displaced
precedents.cited_holding: the Wajib-ul-arz, though it does not create a title, gives rise to a presumption in its support which prevails unless the presumption is properly displaced

anchor.surface_text: It is also true that the Wajib ul-arz being part of a revenue record is of greater authority than a Riwaji-i-am which is of general application and which is not drawn up in respect of individual villages  Gurbakhsh Singh v. Mst. Partapo 1  . Whether the statutory presumption attaching to an entry in the Wajib-ul-arz has been properly displaced or not must depend on the facts of each case.

precedents.cited_proposition: the Wajib ul-arz being part of a revenue record is of greater authority than a Riwaji-i-am which is of general application and which is not drawn up in respect of individual villages
